Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating Temperature, Melting, and Mantle Flow in the North American Upper Mantle with 3-D Models of Shear Velocity, Radial Anisotropy, and Attenuation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The continent of North America is geologically and tectonically diverse. The western half of the continent includes a major plate boundary and has been host to mountain-building events, volcanism, and extension within the recent geological past. The eastern portion of North America is located far from any plate boundary and has not experienced significant tectonic activity in hundreds of millions of years. Understanding how the dynamic processes occurring in Earth's interior have given rise to this complex terrain is fundamental to understanding the growth and evolution of continents in general and North America in particular. Imaging variations in the speed of seismic waves traveling through the crust and mantle provides important constraints on the temperature and composition of those regions as well as the presence of partially molten rock. However, since each of these factors, and any combination of them, can affect velocity, additional data sets are needed to achieve a robust interpretation. The absorption of seismic-wave energy is also controlled by temperature, composition, and melt content, and thus jointly interpreting variations in seismic-wave velocity and attenuation allows for improved constraints on the properties of Earth's interior. To date, there have been very few studies of seismic attenuation beneath North America, largely because of the difficulties involved with measuring and analyzing the amplitudes of seismic waves.

The PIs will develop 3-D models of shear attenuation and radially anisotropic shear velocity for the North American upper mantle using surface waves recorded by USArray. Surface-wave phase and amplitude are measured using a new interstation cross-correlation approach that exploits waveform similarity at nearby stations, and the phase and amplitude data will be utilized together to take advantage of the dependence of both data sets on seismic velocity and attenuation. From these models, variations in temperature, composition, and partial melt across the continent will be estimated, and a more complete picture of how structures like the Colorado Plateau, the Basin and Range, the Mid-Continent Rift, and the North American craton are controlled by the processes in and properties of the underlying mantle will emerge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The North American continent contains vastly diverse geology, with dramatic volcanoes and mountains in the west, flat plains across the interior, and gentle hills along the eastern seaboard. This topography reflects the many episodes of continental collision, breakup, and modification that the land mass has experienced over billions of years. The movements of the tectonic plates at Earth’s surface cause most volcanism and earthquakes and are inextricably linked to the movement of rocks in Earth’s mantle. This convection in the mantle occurs as heat is transferred from the interior to the surface of the planet. Understanding the connection between the Earth’s interior and surface is essential to addressing fundamental questions about how continents are created, how they evolve over time, and how they are destroyed.

 

This study measured the speed and energy loss experienced by seismic waves as they propagate through the crust and mantle beneath the United States. With measurements of wave speed and energy loss, seismologists can estimate the temperature of the rocks in Earth’s deep interior. These measurements can also tell us about the chemical composition of the rocks, whether the rocks are partially molten, and if there are reservoirs of water and carbon dioxide deep inside the Earth. Our study used 882 earthquakes that occurred around the globe between 2006 and 2015 and 1966 seismic stations, all of which were part of the NSF EarthScope USArray project and located in North America.

 

The main focus of this project was to develop a better understanding of how the energy content of seismic waves changes as the waves travel beneath the U.S. Most studies of seismic waves consider only the speed of seismic waves. Energy loss, or attenuation, is an equally useful but more difficult measurement to make because it uses the wave amplitude, which is easily contaminated by other effects. We showed that seismic wave attenuation is high in the western U.S., low in the interior U.S, and slightly elevated in the east. The transition from high to low attenuation corresponds to the Rocky Mountain Front. We also found that the overall high attenuation in the west is interrupted in several places by extremely low attenuation values. These low-attenuation zones are typically also associated with very low phase velocity; thus, we suspect that these zones are the result of simplifications in our theoretical treatment of wave propagation (notably the treatment of focusing effects) in areas with strong local variations in phase velocity. In summary, this project resulted in the first continent-scale attenuation model for North America and illuminated features that were not previously resolvable, including a transition from high attenuation in the west to low attenuation in the central U.S. that aligns with the Rocky Mountain Front, and elevated attenuation along the eastern seaboard. It also identified anomalous attenuation values that we hypothesize derive from unmodelled propagation effects and will investigate with computer simulations of wave propagation as part of future work.
